items: Hey everyone, this week I dove right into improving the layout features in animint2. I opened [PR #139](https://github.com/animint/animint2/pull/139) where I added three new attributes to `theme_animint`: `rowspan`, `colspan`, and `last_in_row`. These make it way easier to create flexible grid layouts for multiple plots.

For example, setting `rowspan=2` lets a plot take up two rows instead of the default one, `colspan=2` spans it across two columns, and `last_in_row=TRUE` makes sure the plot closes off the current row in the HTML table—super handy for clean rendering!

I also tackled a tricky bug with `geom_raster()` that was causing silent failures and messing up plot renders. I raised [PR #204](https://github.com/animint/animint2/pull/204) to fix it, adding better error reporting so developers get useful feedback instead of crashes.
I spent time exploring how `theme_animint()` uses HTML tables to manage plot layouts, which was fascinating.
I started building the rendering logic to handle all sorts of rowspan and colspan combos—it's coming along nicely.
Figuring out the root cause of the `geom_raster` issue was a bit of a puzzle, but I implemented a solid error-handling fix to keep things stable.

learnings.content: This week taught me a lot about how R's declarative themes can shape HTML visualizations. Debugging those silent failures in layered systems like animint2 was eye-opening—it really honed my problem-solving skills.

items: I'm planning to keep polishing the layout logic and wrap up [PR #139](https://github.com/animint/animint2/pull/139).
Then, I'll start on [Issue #143](https://github.com/animint/animint2/issues/143) to handle some edge cases with nested selectors in layouts.

Building on last week, I kept pushing forward with [PR #139](https://github.com/animint/animint2/pull/139) to enhance layout handling in `theme_animint()`. It's all about making those multi-plot setups more intuitive.
I also began porting some demo visualizations over to the [Gallery](https://github.com/animint/gallery), which is a great spot for sharing interactive plots with the community.
I improved the logic for edge cases and complex colspan/rowspan mixes—testing them out felt rewarding as things started clicking into place.

I shifted gears to migrate some rselenium code over to chromote, which promises better browser automation.
At the same time, I kept refining the layout work in [PR #139](https://github.com/animint/animint2/pull/139).
I've been learning the ins and outs of chromote testing—it's powerful stuff for automation.
Finally wrapped up the layout logic in [PR #139](https://github.com/animint/animint2/pull/139)—feels great to have that solid.
Got [PR #204](https://github.com/animint/animint2/pull/204) merged to remove issues with Geom Raster—big win!
Now tackling [Issue #143](https://github.com/animint/animint2/issues/143) by migrating rselenium code to chromote.
Diving deep into chromote testing and how it integrates.
Explored how Shiny apps play with animint2—lots of connections to make.
Figuring out the conversion from rselenium to chromote has been a hands-on learning curve.

learnings.content: This week was intense—I learned to use chromote for testing and how to run Shiny apps effectively. It took a while to sort everything out, so I couldn't commit daily, but the progress feels real and valuable.
